content.webTitle: Me and my travels: Rosie Stancer

fields.headline: Me and my travels
fields.bodyText: When I was at the North Pole ... I was eating a diet of 5,500 calories a day and I still lost weight. I would start the day with a hearty porridge with butter, cream and sugar. My marching rations would be neat butter, shortbread, and I always had a Mars bar unwrapped and cut up so I could suck on it. In the evening I had space food - it might sound revolting, but you are literally starving so it all tastes sublime. On an expedition I never travel without ... A photograph of my husband and my little boy and a special protection prayer which I carry with me. Loneliness is ... Part of the adventure and challenge of the poles. It intensifies the whole experience. The poles have great beauty and allure and you become smitten. My most memorable meal was ... In China. We arrived tired and extremely hungry at this one-horse town with just a couple of dusty shacks, one with a filthy sign swinging in the wind. Inside there was a room with three old kitchen tables and a couple of tin buckets, one containing cabbage, the other two fish of no great dimension. But from this came the most delicious 10-course lunch. You should always ... Make a beeline for the local eating house, no matter what it looks like. My mother's top tip on finding the best place to eat in Rome is to follow a priest or a monk. I suppose one of the few pleasures they allow themselves is the lust of the palate. My favourite hotel is ... My cousin's place in Lochmaddy on North Uist. It's a lovely muddy-grand type of affair. You can stalk and fish and eat lovely fresh food and relax. I always bring back ... The most impractical things like huge casks of oil from Italy or bags of enormous shells. The most extraordinary thing I've returned home with was melted ice from 90 degrees south. My goddaughter was baptised with it. I no longer travel with ... This one particular suitcase. It was just too unlucky. The final straw was on my honeymoon. We had flown off to south Brazil - and it went north. My worst holiday ... Was to the south coast of Spain near Marbella in the early 1980s. It was incredibly tacky - full of men with hairy chests and big gold chains driving convertible Mercedes. The water was so filthy you had to take a boat out to swim in the sea. Thankfully we met up with some friends. Once you've got good company, you can enjoy anything. On holidays, I always take ... Earplugs and a sense of humour. That will carry you through anything. · Rosie Stancer returned last week from an attempt to become the first woman to reach the North Pole alone. Despite losing three toes to frostbite she got within 89 miles of the pole before being forced to abandon because pilots feared storms would prevent them collecting her.
